importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the announcement of the expulsion of two top generals from the Chinese Communist Party and military, marking a significant development in China’s anti-corruption campaign.
The start date of the broader anti-corruption drive in the People’s Liberation Army that has led to the purging of senior military officials.
The date when U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit to Taiwan prompted aggressive military drills involving General He, highlighting his role in regional military strategy.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which China's anti-corruption campaign in the military has intensified, resulting in the removal of multiple senior officials, including top generals.
A period of heightened military activity in response to U.S.-Taiwan tensions, during which General He played a key strategic role in planning live-fire drills.

keyTakeAways: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and military over corruption charges.
He Weidong, the number two general and former vice-chair of the Central Military Commission, is the first sitting general on the Central Military Commission to be expelled since 1966–1976.
Miao Hua, former top political officer of the navy, was previously under investigation and removed from the Central Military Commission in June.
The removals are part of President Xi Jinping’s broader anti-corruption campaign, signaling a consolidation of power within the military and political leadership.
The expulsions come just before the Central Committee’s Fourth Plenum, where new appointments, including replacements in the Central Military Commission, are expected.
He Weidong has close ties to President Xi Jinping, having served together in Fujian and Zhejiang provinces in the late 1990s and later commanding key regional military units.
He played a central role in planning aggressive live-fire drills around Taiwan after Nancy Pelosi’s visit in August 2022, indicating his strategic importance in China’s cross-strait policy.
The purge involves not only military officers but also political figures, such as Former People’s Armed Police Commander Wang Chunning, who was removed from the national legislature.
The investigation of He Weidong had not been publicly disclosed prior to the announcement, highlighting a lack of transparency in China’s internal party investigations.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Two top Chinese military leaders, He Weidong and Miao Hua, have been expelled from the Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army over corruption charges, marking one of the most significant purges of senior military officials since the 1966–1976 Cultural Revolution. He Weidong, the second-highest-ranking general and former vice-chair of the Central Military Commission, is particularly notable due to his close ties with President Xi Jinping and his role in planning aggressive military drills around Taiwan following U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s visit in 2022. The expulsions are part of a broader anti-corruption campaign initiated in 2023 and are expected to be formalized at the upcoming Central Committee Fourth Plenum. These actions signal a consolidation of power within the military and party leadership, with implications not only for China’s internal governance but also for regional stability, especially in cross-strait relations. Other officials, including former political commissars and military commanders, have also been removed, indicating a wide-reaching effort to purge perceived corruption and ensure loyalty to the central authority.
title: China expels two top generals from Communist Party in anti-corruption crackdown
